metadata.case_name: Added Respondent No. 7 & State of Bombay v. Plaintiff-Respondent
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 287 of 1955 and 288 of 1955

facts.text: Suit properties at Malgaon and Takli wrongfully resumed by Miraj State in 1910 as part of State Sheri-Khata.
Narso, recorded owner of suit properties, died in 1910. Defendants 4 to 7 belong to his family but did not contest.
After inquiry, order dated July 31, 1915, to record lands as Sheri-Khata and appropriate usufruct to Khasgi-Khata of State.
Defendants 2 and 3, plaintiff's brothers, relinquished interest in suit properties in favour of plaintiff.

Proclamation by State Karabhari, Miraj State, on January 1, 1926, made Indian Limitation Act IX of 1908 applicable from February 1, 1926, with modification allowing suits till January 31, 1929, that were in time under old 20-year law.

Plaintiff instituted suit on January 31, 1929 (last day of limitation) in Munsiff's Court at Miraj, registered as Original Suit No. 724 of 1930. Prayed for possession and mesne profits. Valued at Rs. 2,065 (5 times assessment) for court-fee; no valuation for jurisdiction.
Similar Tikoni suit by plaintiff in same court: Original Suit No. 443 of 1928, dismissed on November 29, 1939.
Plaintiff's application on June 21, 1940, stating value of subject-matter 8-10 thousand rupees, beyond Munsiff's jurisdiction. Court allowed, returned plaint on July 4, 1940.
Plaint re-presented on July 4, 1940, to District Judge at Miraj, numbered Suit No. 2 of 1940. State of Miraj (first defendant) contested including on limitation.
Defendant's petition October 27, 1942: Plaintiff knew value exceeded jurisdiction, act not bona fide.
District Judge, Miraj, dismissed suit with costs on December 12, 1945.

Plaintiff appealed; during pendency, State of Bombay added as 6th respondent, Yuvaraj of Miraj (Madhavrao Narayanarao) as 7th respondent (acquired interest by grant). Appeal: First Appeal No. 104 of 1950, Bombay High Court.
Division Bench, Bombay High Court, allowed appeal, decreed suit with costs against first and 7th respondents on November 30, 1951.
Respondents 6 and 7 obtained certificate, appealed to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal Nos. 287/1955 (added resp 7) and 288/1955 (State of Bombay).

legal_issues.text: Whether plaintiff entitled to benefit of section 14 of Limitation Act for time between January 31, 1929 (original filing in Munsiff's Court) and July 4, 1940 (re-presentation in District Court), i.e., was previous suit prosecuted with due diligence and in good faith in court lacking jurisdiction.
Alternatively, whether suit barred by 12 years under Art. 142 Limitation Act from 1910 or 1915.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaintiff not entitled to section 14 benefit: did not prosecute with due diligence; not in good faith (knew value exceeded jurisdiction, omitted valuation deliberately, moved for return after Tikoni dismissal). Suit barred on re-presentation July 4, 1940.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 14 Limitation Act; definition of good faith in s.2(7) Limitation Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Even with section 14 benefit, suit barred under Art. 142 (12 years) from 1910 (Narso's death) or 1915 (final order).

respondent_arguments.text: Courts below right: entitled to exclude time from January 31, 1929 to July 4, 1940 under section 14; original suit within time.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff must affirmatively show: (1) prosecuting with due diligence, (2) same cause of action, (3) good faith, (4) court unable due to jurisdiction defect. Conditions 2 and 4 satisfied, but 1 and 3 not: no evidence of diligence (no order-sheet); no good faith (s.2(7) requires due care/attention; omitted valuation despite knowing value >Rs.5000, unlike Tikoni suit; moved after Tikoni dismissal; plaintiff drafted plaint himself). Lower courts erred shifting burden to defendant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission to mention value not due care; plaintiff responsible for plaint; no proof of diligence over 10+ years.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide Art.142 issue as suit barred without s.14 benefit.

holdings.text: Plaintiff not entitled to section 14 benefit; suit instituted July 4, 1940 barred by limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs exclusion of time for prior proceeding lacking jurisdiction if prosecuted diligently in good faith; good faith defined as with due care and attention; 12-year limitation for possession.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed; High Court judgment and decree reversed; suit dismissed as barred by limitation; costs throughout.

key_quotes.text: "In computing the period of limitation prescribed for any suit, the time during which the plaintiff has been prosecuting with due diligence another civil proceeding... shall be excluded, where the proceeding... is prosecuted in good faith in a Court which, from defect of jurisdiction... is unable to entertain it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.14(1) Limitation Act, central to issue

key_quotes.text: "Nothing shall be deemed to be done in good faith which is not done with due care and attention - section 2(7)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes from General Clauses Act; key to denying good faith

key_quotes.text: The plaintiffs mala fides are therefore not established and the period occupied in prosecuting the former suit must be excluded under section 14 of the Limitation Act.
key_quotes.speaker: district_judge
key_quotes.significance: Trial court conclusion reversed by SC

key_quotes.text: "We do not see our way to accuse the plaintiff of want of good faith or any mala fides in the matter of the filing of the suit in the Subordinate Judges Court at Miraj."
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court error in burden of proof, reversed
